channel.title: Robot class?
channel.description: What all can you do with the Java robot class? I know that it can automate a lot of what your computer can do.. But what kind of things can be made with this? The potential for bots for games to be made? The potential to automate messages to random people on forums? I'm new to this whole robot class thing. I more or less stumbled upon it when I was reading my Java book.

item.title: Robot class?
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

Revitalize:

I will re-code it just for one instance.

You don’t need to re-code it, lol. just remove 2 lines with 1 instead.

Robot clicker = new Robot();
Robot bot = new Robot();

Read full topic

item.title: Robot class?
item.dc:creator: @Revitalize Revitalize
item.description:
@Revitalize wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:8, topic:523898”][quote author=Revitalize link=topic=642443.msg4327756#msg4327756 date=1373224331]
Does it slow down the code to use more than one? Again, I’m new to this
[/quote]

It’s simply bad practice. In some situations, recreating the class also recreates the context you’re working with, which means you may get bizarre or incorrect behavior. Robot should work with multiple instances, but it’s much more efficient to just use one.

@your code: one reason it may not be working is because in your click function, you’re sending the click events and then proceeding to move the mouse to some location, then click again. You’re moving the mouse, clicking, moving again, clicking, and then repeating this over a dozen times. Is this the correct behavior? If not, relook over your code.[/quote]

It is supposed to(: okay, I will re-code it just for one instance. I just need to figure out inheritance. I haven’t mastered that yet, as simple as that is…

Read full topic

item.title: Robot class?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Revitalize:

Does it slow down the code to use more than one? Again, I’m new to this

It’s simply bad practice. In some situations, recreating the class also recreates the context you’re working with, which means you may get bizarre or incorrect behavior. Robot should work with multiple instances, but it’s much more efficient to just use one.

@your code: one reason it may not be working is because in your click function, you’re sending the click events and then proceeding to move the mouse to some location, then click again. You’re moving the mouse, clicking, moving again, clicking, and then repeating this over a dozen times. Is this the correct behavior? If not, relook over your code.

Read full topic

item.title: Robot class?
item.dc:creator: @Revitalize Revitalize
item.description:
@Revitalize wrote:

So, I made a simple bot to craft in my server, but how can I set my code up to work within the x-y area of the game screen?

Please, excuse everything if it’s wrong, I’m new to coding…

package Bot;

import java.awt.Robot;
import java.awt.AWTException;
import java.awt.event.*;

/**
*
*
*/
public class Bot {

public static void main(String args[]) {
   /**
 *
 */ 
       try {
        
        Robot bot = new Robot();
        
        
        bot.mouseMove(580, 280);
        click();
        bot.mouseMove(620, 280);
        click();
        bot.mouseMove(663,280);
        click();
        bot.mouseMove(705, 280);
        click();
        bot.mouseMove(580, 315);
        click();
        bot.mouseMove(620, 315);
        click();
        bot.mouseMove(663, 315);
        click();
        bot.mouseMove(705, 315);
        click();
        bot.mouseMove(580, 350);
        click();
        bot.mouseMove(620, 350);
        click();
        bot.mouseMove(663, 350);
        click();
        bot.mouseMove(705, 350);
        click();
       // System.out.println("Bot tested!");
        
    } catch (AWTException e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }

}
public static void click(){
    try {
        Robot clicker = new Robot();
        clicker.delay(10);
        clicker.mousePress(InputEvent.BUTTON1_MASK);
        clicker.mouseRelease(InputEvent.BUTTON1_MASK);
        clicker.delay(120);
        clicker.mouseMove(580, 280);
        clicker.mousePress(InputEvent.BUTTON1_MASK);
        clicker.mouseRelease(InputEvent.BUTTON1_MASK);
        clicker.delay(500);
} catch (AWTException e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
}
}

}

Read full topic

item.title: Robot class?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:3, topic:523898”]It’s useful as a really quick way to automate the mouse, keyboard, or to grab screenshots of the screen. All of these functions are clunky and slow, not to mention inconvenient for something like a bot. Directly manipulate the operating system’s message queue or explicitly downloading the contents of a game’s primary frame buffer or the main screen frame buffer used by the OS can be done using much faster functions and avoid a lot of the pitfalls of robot, at the cost of more knowledge, development time, and usage of JNI or JNA.

It’s a very useful class to have sitting around.[/quote]Yeah I remember it being too slow to move the mouse fluently.

Read full topic

item.title: Robot class?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

It’s useful as a really quick way to automate the mouse, keyboard, or to grab screenshots of the screen. All of these functions are clunky and slow, not to mention inconvenient for something like a bot. Directly manipulate the operating system’s message queue or explicitly downloading the contents of a game’s primary frame buffer or the main screen frame buffer used by the OS can be done using much faster functions and avoid a lot of the pitfalls of robot, at the cost of more knowledge, development time, and usage of JNI or JNA.

It’s a very useful class to have sitting around.

Read full topic

item.title: Robot class?
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

In the Javadocs of the class it states the following:

This class is used to generate native system input events for the purposes of test automation, self-running demos, and other applications where control of the mouse and keyboard is needed. The primary purpose of Robot is to facilitate automated testing of Java platform implementations.

Read full topic
